output: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Siebeck for the work he has done, because his report addresses many of the concerns expressed in this...

The camera focuses on these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be a problem only for the countries of southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report for which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate the prices of raw materials, an aspect that, in the current times, I also think it is very important to point out, so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Committee on the Environment also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action that is mentioned in the report of the Committee on Agriculture and that I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text that will be put to a vote tomorrow does not, however, include a proposal made by the Committee on Agriculture to study the establishment of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose again to Parliament when the Commission publishes its communication on adaptation to climate change in the coming months.

I believe that after the Solidarity Fund was established, which was created to mitigate losses caused by climate calamities, it is time for us to think about an instrument that acts beforehand and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.
Atlético de Madrid, the fans and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case goes beyond the particular, as these federal bodies aggravate the sanctions for those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this law of the funnel, is incompatible with the law, with the European institutions, from which we must react.

And we will eventually do it, because those medieval gentlemen, arbitrary hangmen and knife-wielders, must align themselves with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.
Mr President, Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and so is the action of serious organised crime, and therefore the means must be proportionate and must be fought effectively.

I have taken good note of the answers you have given to the relevant questions. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a sensitive issue, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable to put together, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism is a bit far away, they are more concerned about individual guarantees.
I am concerned about both individual and collective issues, and it is absolutely necessary that we start where we can.
If we have started with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let us demand guarantees, see what the scope is, start with international transport relations and, be careful, we will have to follow up on domestic ones because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
ask the United States and ask others, that's the way it is and that's how we'll have to approach it.
Mr President, I want to thank the Commission for bringing forward this proposal.
I believe it is a positive proposal and that it will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as the speakers who preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to bring down to earth what are very generous and very altruistic proposals on the part of the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are twenty-seven countries with different legal systems and very different languages, which requires that in each of those countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset pointed out just now and as previous speakers have noted, it is important that the recognition of these national specialties does not lead to an increase in costs, that the fees are uniform, and that governments eventually assume that additional cost.
But there is one theme that also appears, and that is the theme of translations.
Concretely, in the European Union we do not have a common language
In the twenty-seven countries, very different languages are usually spoken, even in some countries, like the Commissioner's, different languages are spoken and we live with this.
And from a legal point of view, we are also faced with the reality that legal documents are different.
The Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments on the authentication of minutes, documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At present, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic instruments in different countries of the European Union, which should complement this report.
In conclusion, I believe that the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The rapporteur has done a magnificent job and I believe we have all strived to draft a legislative text that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing human rights.
rights and starting from the basis of the reality of a union that is being built, which has different national systems and which has different levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr President, a large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting the decisions and prior agreements that the Council of Agriculture Ministers of the Union will adopt between today and tomorrow on this Union check-up.
the CAP, because it is not a simple review, but will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if this cut proposed by the European Commission on direct aid goes ahead.

Modulation is the focal point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion to have any impact on the negotiations being conducted by the EU's Agriculture Ministers.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not...
not due to a lack of resources within the CAP expenditure ceiling, but due to an absolute absence of political will to provide the Community budget with the necessary development of this key pillar.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Sure, do it, but with the same requirements and conditions for all producers, both inside and outside the Union.

At this moment, the European Union is deciding the future of many farmers and ranchers, and I would especially like to refer to fragile sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this review.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep industry, no longer ask for aid, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the math and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only option we leave to many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
Parliament should issue a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture for the efforts made by Mr. París to ensure that Parliament is heard and not so blatantly and obviously ignored by the Council and the Commission as has been the case up to now.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to join the rapporteur, Mr Capelas Santos, in congratulating him on his excellent work.
I think he has found balance and moderation in his report.
I believe that what is important at this stage of the debate is to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Commissioner, the same solutions do not work for all sectors.
And we must remember that we have sectors that are going through real difficulties.
The common agricultural policy does not have to be the problem, but the solution, and for that we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not about strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified, and that market instruments need to be reviewed.
But that doesn't mean dismantling them.
If we do it right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.

We are facing a plan that has been highly anticipated by the fruit and vegetable sector, not only because of the difficulties it is experiencing, but also because of the worrying decline in consumption.
We are dealing with a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also advocate for full Community funding.

I don't agree that parents can participate in co-financing, because the same thing will happen as always. The children of parents who can contribute money will consume fruits and vegetables at school, while those who can't will be left out of the program.
I believe it has to be a community-funded plan for its distribution to be homogeneous.
That is why I also want to strongly emphasize that we must focus on educational measures.

It is not just about a student eating an apple, but about knowing what type of apple they are eating, understanding its nutritional properties, and comprehending the beneficial effects that this fruit has on their health and development.

Of course, these must be products with all the quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, whenever possible, I advocate for the Community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the Commissioner, will be immediately noticeable, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

foodstuffs, but I also believe it is very important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage, as it allows us to enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I believe it is worth betting on and investing in this plan to distribute fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I think the budget is a bit short, because I repeat that I advocate for full community funding for a plan as ambitious as this one.
Mr. President, I ask that you do not include these opening words in the infernal time machine, please.
My first words are to join in the message of condolence expressed by this House to Mrs Klaas and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now I'm really going to start.

I congratulate the speakers because with these two proposals we are taking a significant step towards a common immigration policy and are entering the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the comprehensive approach we advocate.
The general framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal immigrants should be extended to as many workers as possible.
That is why socialists demand that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
it opens up a unique door to twenty-seven job markets.
However, this door should not only be used by highly skilled workers.
Therefore, Commissioner, we expect the Commission to present its proposals on the other occupational categories to us shortly.
Ladies and gentlemen, we must fight against the brain drain.
This blue card must not become a passport that facilitates a drain of vital human resources from developing countries.
That is why, from the Socialist Group, we want for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we should pay for the training of a new professional in the country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination, not only for talent from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly three hundred thousand highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let's do everything possible to keep them in the European House.
Madam Vice-President, do you think that the proximity or distance of candidates from voters has anything to do with the level of participation in European elections?
European. Do you agree that a state with forty-five million inhabitants should have only one electoral district for elections to the European Parliament?
European, what can the Commission do to ensure that states with larger populations have constituencies that are closer to the citizens?
Excuse me, but I haven't heard the Vice-President respond to my questions.
Thank you very much, Madam President. You have given me quite a bit of information on the issue I raised and I appreciate that detailed information.
I believe that the new phase of the Commission is important, and above all, the Bamako project for a European Union center for immigration.

I know it has just been launched, which is probably very early on, but the question I put to the Commission is, in the event that this Bamako-Bali project on immigration yields good results, does the Commission believe it is possible to extend this experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I appreciate the response on behalf of Mr. Yáñez, but I must say, Commissioner, to Mr. Michel, that his actions, his words, and his gestures are very necessary in direct contact.
really with the Cuban democratic opposition to fulfill the Council's priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favor of freedom.
Mr President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I want to express my Group's strongest condemnation of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, we already know the way this atrocious murder was committed: a 13-year-old girl is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her and even prevent anyone from trying to save her in a stadium filled with a thousand people.
This, combined with the acts of piracy that have reached a level of nearly a hundred hijacked ships off the coast of Somalia this year, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
One cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit barbarity.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia to regain control of the entire country and establish a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that rarely have we been presented with a situation that is so clear and that imposes obligations on us.
I don't believe we can stand idly by in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but I certainly believe that it must be done and that we must act quickly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that have been presented at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this will be the beginning of a greater concern for the European Union for this type of humanitarian issues and for the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit barbarity in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council.
It is a recognition that weapons and ammunition are also part of the internal market, although, of course, with a number of limitations.
These are not normal goods, they are not candies or entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Of course, there are limitations in the Treaty itself, Article 30 and Article 296, which confer important responsibilities on the States in this area.
And the fact that we had a common market does not prevent the states from being obliged to comply with safety standards and, with good reason, from applying them when their own safety is at risk.

The work done in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the opinion committees that have collaborated with them, in accordance with the Council, under the expert guidance of the rapporteur, Mrs. Ruile, has been very positive.
I believe that the text we are presenting today is a fairly balanced text.

Basically, even though on paper there seem to be many amendments, today we are limited to just one amendment, which is Amendment 63, which captures the spirit of compromise, and in that amendment you can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Tubón pointed out that this is related to other international texts.

For example, the adoption this month of the Oslo Convention, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the prohibition of cluster munitions, as well as the Convention on the limitations of anti-personnel mines and a whole series of international agreements and even European Union standards aimed at limiting the use of weapons.
I believe our model is not one of free circulation of weapons at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by the states and also, from now on, by the European Union's own institutions.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal came from the Commission over a year ago, with some truly very ambitious objectives.
At this time, financial convulsions have occurred worldwide that seemed like they would sink these measures, but in the end, a balanced agreement was reached.
it doesn't satisfy almost anyone one hundred percent, but it's a good agreement that maintains the final objectives, but makes the means to achieve them more affordable for companies.

That is why we must express our deepest gratitude and congratulations to the rapporteur, Mrs Doyle, to the rapporteurs of the other political groups and to the French Presidency, especially because their work has led to a good outcome for everyone.

I am confident that in the near future circumstances will allow us to be much more ambitious and that other countries will also join this crusade to combat climate change that we so wish to carry out in Europe.
Mr President, Commissioner, this was a good proposal as it came out of the Commission, not only because of the sulphur reductions, but also because of its new Article 7a which required suppliers to.
gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it solved the old problem of vapor pressure for blends of gasoline with bioalcohol in countries like mine with hot summers.
Precisely this did not pass the vote filter in the Committee on the Environment and this concerned many of us.

Today we have an agreement on the table that softens the application of Article 7 bis and that reintroduces the waiver for vapour pressure, while, of course, tightening the conditions for accessing the exception.
and that, as with the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone one hundred percent, but, nevertheless, it is acceptable to everyone.

I want to thank Mrs Corbey for her excellent work, for the receptiveness she has shown in solving problems, also Mr Turmes and, of course, the French Presidency, who have also demonstrated great effectiveness here.
as the report states, according to 2007 estimates, Zimbabwe has a population of twelve million, nearly half of whom are going hungry.

The life expectancy is thirty-six years and only forty percent of the country's teachers are working and only one-third of the students attend classes, so Mugabe is not only killing the present, he is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights is also on the agenda.
Human rights defenders in Zimbabwe have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detentions, arrests, and torture.
Legislation introduced by the government severely restricts freedoms of speech, assembly, movement, and association.
I would like to cite several of them, as the government has introduced increasingly repressive regulations, which have been used against these human rights activist defenders.

For example, the Law on Access to Information and Protection of Privacy, used by the Government to effectively silence journalists, the Law on Public Order and Security, which has severely limited freedom of assembly, and hundreds of...

Human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily detained, and the law on private voluntary organizations, re-established in 2002 by the government, has allegedly been used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my mother tongue, Euskara, Basque, which is not official in this Chamber, Mugabe means without limit, a good nickname for this character.

The dictator of that African country is not just another one in the long list of dictators that, unfortunately, we have on this planet, but I dare say that he occupies one of the top ten positions among dictators.
I believe that in the EU we must do the impossible to ensure that this character leaves and spends the rest of his days sitting before a Human Rights Court.
We therefore wish Zimbabwe a happy year 2009 without Mugabe.
We have a proposed resolution on Nicaragua that needs to address different aspects.
First, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this tarnishes the election results of November 9.
On the other hand, we have a government that has taken steps to address some of the issues that undermine human rights in Latin America.
specifically poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, the availability of potable water, and the lack of title to indigenous lands.
So, when examining the case, we have to clearly distinguish between the two aspects.

On the one hand, we need to promote human rights and defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other hand, we need to encourage the Government of Nicaragua to continue its role in helping the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must ensure that the opposition can carry out its function, we must oppose fraud, but we must also defend the actions of NGOs.
But, however, one must have a balanced result.
The Socialist Group has tabled several oral amendment proposals, seeking to steer the final text towards being more balanced with regard to the allegations of.
violations of fundamental rights, with respect to whether the investigations are criminal or not, and with respect to the number of municipalities in which some type of derogation has occurred.

In short, we want to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of placing the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult situation to continue fulfilling its function of supporting the most needy sectors of society.
On the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms and against democracy.
There is no need to recall Zoila América, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez, or the many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega asked the Nicaraguans and democratically obtained what he called a new opportunity.
Today we already know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism, and corruption have taken root in the government institutions, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9 elections.

Very serious decisions had previously been made, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of some opposition parties, threats and intimidation of civil society members, journalists, and the media.
President Ortega called the governments of the European Union flies that swarm over filth and described the foreign aid that Nicaragua received as crumbs.
soon he understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

As we are about to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua must know that it will always find an ally and a friend in us.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy in general is a condition to which we will not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua especially benefit from it.
Municipal elections were held in Nicaragua last November 9.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been called into question from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and...
demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been suffering from.
Two political parties have been unable to run in the local elections, which is unacceptable because it undermines the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

about the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought up to seventeen social movement organizations to court, about the persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all these reasons, we want to raise our voice and make an appeal, first, to the political parties to condemn the acts of violence carried out by their followers and, second, to the government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

citizen, that freedom of expression is respected, that marches are no longer banned, and that all NGOs can receive aid from international cooperation, not just those from Venezuela, for pro-government associations.
Similarly, that they repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases of danger to the life of the mother.

And finally, we also want to ask the Commission that in the negotiations of the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union, it reminds Nicaragua that it must respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all of this without prejudice to the fact that from Europe we continue to provide our aid for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, who we wish to have the best possible future.
Madam President, I am going to refer to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that particular attention must be paid to human health and also to environmental protection when using plant protection products.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this Regulation may have in the future.
And there are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that, due to the scarce future availability of plant protection products, it will be very difficult to achieve the goal.
control of pests and diseases that affect the cultivation of large quantities of food, particularly all Mediterranean products, and also the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement reached in the tripartite dialogue has been the result of intense negotiations and I cannot fail to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

But, nevertheless, it must be taken into account that the temporary definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, which are of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient quantity of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger often lies not in the product itself, but in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the EPP Group in the European Parliament supports the proposals that call for an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
by Mr. Stardy, which I myself have signed, concerning endocrine disruptors and those that promote the availability of plant protection products in case of emergency.

Moreover, if this Regulation is adopted under the terms of the Agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices, which will lead us to import those same foods that we do not produce, treated with the products that we are prohibiting.
Mr President, Mr Capato, your report is full of good will. The most obvious proof of this is that it did not deserve any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Freedoms.
You yourself introduced eighteen amendments to your own report.
And those amendments are the ones that have introduced an added radicalism to that report, let's put it that way, in general terms, which gives me very serious doubts.
I would set out the amendments you have proposed, which you have proposed to yourself, in four distinct sections, I insist, in a report that received the support of all groups at the beginning.
Some impossible ones. You ask for some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are asking for things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, until the Lisbon Treaty comes into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
something similar to what Commissioner Wallström just said. You are asking, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no longer any time frame.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
In addition, it asks for some others that are not recommended.
For example, you ask for transparency in the meetings of the political groups.
No, less.
privacy is necessary. Privacy is a political asset.
If I want to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not within the parties, where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
Therefore, I cannot follow you on that.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that ninety percent of legislative activity is due to comitology.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And, moreover, criminology inherently implies certain norms of transparency.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to pursue, which is transparency, which is something that is very close to simplicity.
Lastly, before the chairman calls me to order, because I am already running out of time, there are some things that are unnecessary.

For example, I understand that it is very popular and very attractive to public opinion to talk about transparency in the activities of Members of Parliament, that it is known that they dance during plenary sessions.
You already know that, Mr. Capato.
or those who go to the commissions, it is already known if there is a record of all of them, as these are acts that are accessible to all citizens.
or the diets that are paid. You already know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very appealing to public opinion and very flattering to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is about making things look the way they are. And when one contributes to making things not look the way they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.
I view the situation in Gaza with horror, pain, and shame, but also with a commitment to defend peace and those who suffer the most, and to maintain dignity and hope.
horror at the repeated scene of murdered children and women torn apart in their endless suffering following the bombings of the ghetto that Gaza has become.
the same horror that Picasso painted in his Guernica, our Guernica razed by the Junkers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
shared pain with so many victims of so much suffering.
and shame for the inability of everyone, of our States, of the European Union and of the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression that we denounce.
Shame and indignation at so much lying, so much ambiguity, and so much empty talk.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and required decisiveness and coherence.
History will therefore hold many accountable as accomplices to the crime, if only by omission.
Because better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door open to hope, the European Union must support the Security Council's belated resolution.

which must be strictly adhered to, just as our Association Agreement with Israel must be strictly adhered to, which provides for its suspension in the face of conduct such as that which is currently taking place.
By the way, it is also responsible for the media blackout that I have not heard anyone denounce so far.

We must say with clear and unequivocal force to Israel that it must stop killing, allow the wounded to be treated and the affected to be fed, and that its attitude against international law must have consequences in its relations with Europe.
I want to salute the few young European volunteers who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, in particular Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of our Europe, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Madam President, Commissioner, as we can see, the textile sector has been experiencing a major crisis in recent times, which has led to numerous company closures, relocations, and unemployment, all of which are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

Given the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I think it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are undergoing restructuring and are currently in serious trouble.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and requalification of the textile sector.
This is particularly true for small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and are most affected by the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to re-establish the control system for imports from abroad, and especially, due to their volume, from China.
This is not at all about promoting trade barriers.

It is about compensating for the negative effects of such an important transformation. And we must also not forget that the European Union is the second largest exporter of textile products and clothing in the world.

That is to say, which makes it necessary to guarantee the best conditions of access to third-country markets, essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.
All of this, of course, always ensuring fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this sense, the publication of correct information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the Made in indication, which to the best of our knowledge has not been implemented, would be of great utility since.
among other things, it would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr. Romeva, the Spanish government has nothing to worry about; it will cooperate as it always has.

I would like to remind you that in this matter, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Investigative Committee and answered all the questions, including yours.

This. We in this Chamber have been denouncing the torture and inhumane and degrading treatment that has been carried out at the Guantanamo military base in the name of the fight against international terrorism for some time.
That is why we applaud Obama's decision to suspend the trials for four months and his goal to definitively close the prison within a year.
Now, although the responsibility lies with the American government, the Union cannot look the other way and must offer its collaboration to achieve the closure of the detention center.
We must also consider the possibility of accepting prisoners from countries where human rights are not guaranteed, even if the United States does not request it.

Then we will have to give a common European response, in which the Spanish Government will participate, in compliance with the international legal framework and in the analysis of each case, taking into account the legal situation of each citizen, each detainee, their origin, their detention and their situation.

Mr President, in the EU there are various cases of languages of historical European peoples which, because they are not constituted as a state, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language, but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with the Basque Country of the North, which is part of the French State, whose president, before the United Nations Assembly, states that denying respect for national identities and languages is fueling humiliation and that, without that respect, there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, Corsican, Breton, nor Occitan have the slightest official consideration nor do they have support to respect or encourage their use.

Therefore, I ask that the Fundamental Rights Agency ensure and work to guarantee that within the member states, the mother tongue rights of no European people are violated, nor are its inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Skerry Casco, Jan Andreok, Suel Laguncha Gaitik, Europa Co. and Skuncha Agustín Alde.
Madam President, first of all, I want to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this Directive, we demonstrate, once again, our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The aim of this Directive is clear: to combat mafias, punish unscrupulous employers and protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.
We want to see an end to the unjust poverty wages paid to immigrants, which also distort average wages, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, and hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and a lot of money circulating in the underground economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
The easy thing would be to give in to the temptation of not trying to tackle the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave some eight million irregular immigrants in a state of defenselessness, with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal penalties are necessary in the most aggravated cases, which have a deterrent effect on employers.
This will help us reduce the informal economy and cut off the incentive for migration that is generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It should be clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

That is why we want to move forward with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Baró, to present the new blue cards, as soon as possible, for the other occupational categories.
Dear colleagues, Mrs Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana, I would first of all like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work and, as the shadow rapporteur for the report on the CFSP, I will refer to
To this particular report, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Saris Volski on the outcome of his work and on the collaboration offered by the other groups to achieve a consensus result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to equip itself with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, the House itself has also shown itself to be cohesive in evaluating and promoting the major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

Our group's efforts, the Socialist Group, have gone in a dual direction: on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key to us in a transversal manner throughout foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of...

peace throughout the planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, proposing elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CFSP with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or introducing them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and greater relevance in relations with Africa, a continent that we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and even then, not always.

With regard to Latin America, we have wanted to reflect the current negotiation processes for association agreements, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only talks about security, in order to include, instead, the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained in the Barcelona Process.

As for the amendments for the plenary, our Group has not submitted any, believing that this somehow strengthens the balance achieved with the compromises, and therefore, we will oppose most of the amendments so as not to weaken the compromise reached in the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Mr President, the referendum in Venezuela has resulted in a victory for the 'yes' vote, elegantly acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has had the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralist and free path.
In that sense, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish MEP and even more so the way in which such expulsion was carried out, but we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate the local legislation in force and even less so that they insult a head of state, however much this person may be open to criticism.
With these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.

Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral authority as a member of an international electoral observation group for the referendum held last October 15.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, it was noted that they came to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, made serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and bordered on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not encourage any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the honorable deputy to provide explanations to this House about an action that affects us all.
The Budget Committee believes that it is of utmost importance to clearly define each of the budgetary instruments.
Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions other than public development aid for countries that fall within the scope of the said Regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, the proposal for funding from the Development Committee does not seem appropriate, as that money does not exist.
do not count those lines with a multi-year assigned credit amount. There is a credit for 2009, but not for beyond.
In any case, since the funding for this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is advisable to
remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the ceilings for the various headings.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission will probably have other things to worry about more than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a Commission report, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206-2001.
Council Recommendation of 28 May 2001 concerning cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a field that is not truly communitarian; it is an intergovernmental field, in which the Council has attempted to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies through the Regulation.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been envisaged, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc., but I recognize that action by the Commission is quite difficult.

I don't know what the Commission has achieved or plans to achieve, but it seems quite difficult to achieve it because of the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation represents.

In other words, we are asking judicial authorities to cooperate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities who speak 22 different languages, with very different legal systems, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do so.
Ideally, we would have the necessary material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to equip judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any kind of training for judges is fundamental.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own either.
but the Commission can indeed encourage the development of this type of training course in Community law and knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty which is the problem of languages, that is, how can a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
Judges cannot be expected to have knowledge of these kinds of things, in addition to having to deal with their own law, which is complex enough on its own.
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it?
in presenting this report, we should not display any kind of rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I think the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, is what the commission thinks can be done to provide greater...

The rigor of this regulation from the year 2001 is somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntarist, and I'm not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or if progress can be made with it.
Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, the Erika shipwreck, off the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at preventing and avoiding accidents.

We thought we had already averted the danger, but shortly afterwards the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the oil slick from another accident, even bigger than the first one, the one involving the ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have been working on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the many resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various Directives and Regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, due to the cuts made by the Council, they were not effective in their initial drafting.

We approved the regulations for the introduction of double-hull ships, the European Fund for major oil spills, safe havens, and now we are revising and approving the liability of passenger carriers by sea, the investigation of the

maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, port State control and, finally, the regulation and directive concerning ship inspection and survey organizations.
And it is good and desirable that all this can come into force and be applied by all the Member States in the shortest possible time.
That is why I feel satisfied.

But the legislative term is coming to an end, I am leaving Parliament, and I am going away with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of control systems that already exist mandatory.
are patented to determine when and how much waste from ships and fuel tanks has been illegally dumped into the sea by a particular vessel.
That is, a kind of black box tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities every time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better attention and more stringent procedures to address the pollution we produce, which, if left unchecked, will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another ten years to control illegal marine spills more effectively and efficiently.

Mr President, the revision of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially the peripheral countries, who feel they are the victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of external costs of road transport by attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles that inspire the proposal - the polluter pays and the user pays - are reasonable, the proposed solution is by no means reasonable, as it will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if that was not the goal, has turned out to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and, far from achieving the expected goals of sustainable transport, would be the death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer, a consumer who will see how their products become more expensive due to the application of these taxes.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly transportation system, without neglecting the road, because at present it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, cross-border connections are still, in some cases, projects and not a reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the titanium of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joy.

Mr President, on 15 July 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13, pending the Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that as early as the seventh meeting of the European Union-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, held at the end of October last year, we said that one.
This strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary boost to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We note the good state of relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current Global Agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, especially in the face of new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
As a result, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Association, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
I would like, with regard to the report on microcredit, to congratulate all the rapporteurs, because they have done a great job.
have undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations set out here will allow us to establish a foundation for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector.
which has been a success in many developing countries, including some in Europe, both as a mechanism for economic activity and as a tool for improving social inclusion and job creation.
but it had not been transferred to the sector or the community context, and I believe it is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
It is a priority, in this sense, to strengthen the initiatives being advanced here, but more steps need to be taken.
The funds available for this microcredit support structure need to be increased.
We need to facilitate availability for people and businesses that do not have access to loans, and in that regard, I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of the
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate such access and which has been included in the report.
And I end up thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I understand that we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of aid to coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this well in advance because, inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed themselves to express an opposing view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
Support for coal in my country must continue after 2012, and I want this to be recorded in the minutes.

Limit yourselves, gentlemen officials, to complying with the current plan and then, starting in the year two thousand twelve, with the instrument that we will begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Mr President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr Boclan has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention to be held in May.
That is why I want to congratulate Mr Brok, not only for the question, but also for the Resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to dismantle ships and, therefore, we support Mr. Brockland's motion for a resolution. But there are some points that concern us.

The first is section three, which he has also pointed out, which states that ships as a whole should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this point because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted, but it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its implementation.
The motion for a resolution also calls, in its fourteenth point, for a funding mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

We think it is really a bit premature to talk about mandatory contributions at this point when the IMO has not yet decided on the system to be adopted for this funding, and I also think that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this issue either.
Finally, point fifteen urges the Commission to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We also do not believe that it is the Commission's responsibility to decide this, which should also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure consistency between the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the transboundary movement of hazardous waste and its disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we have a great deal of agreement regarding this programme, and congratulate all of us, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a programme like this, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are dealing with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that at this time of economic uncertainty, we in Brussels and Strasbourg are not exclusively concerned.

We are not only concerned about a recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy - we agree with the Commission on this point - not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, but also because it is an instrument that works, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

In the Socialist Group, like the rapporteur, we are opposed to this program being kept confidential between the European Union and the Member States, as this would lead to discrimination between states based on their wealth, and could result in the program not being implemented in the most needy countries.

It is not understood that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wants to save Community money in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full Community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries, and especially those most in need.
Forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and, in no case, should budgetary savings be made.
Austerity yes, but not for the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the programme must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transportation, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be Community-produced and of high quality.
It is a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
That's all and thank you very much.

We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when the vote takes place and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic, not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of large areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for the Antarctic, while taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty between all the parties involved, including the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of human activities of all kinds, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must raise that spirit and that harmony to higher levels to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from becoming embroiled in geostrategic struggles, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good Directive, an excellent Directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When people talk about seeking a smarter model for doing business, what they're really talking about is putting an end to intellectual property.
Because you can only do business if there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under Mr. Macrivi's leadership, has taken a courageous initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the House should approve the compromise we have.
achieved in the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Mrs McGill and Mr Tugong.
I think it is a magnificent directive, one that will promote the creation of intellectual property.
In addition, the Directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval by this House of that report and I hope that the Council will align itself with the lines of the Council, the Commission and Parliament will serve so that in the next legislature the.

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to Parliament, and move forward in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression we European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens have is that we have a very dangerous loophole in Community law.
At the moment, as tax requirements are being reinforced in each of the member states, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a kind of vicious circle where the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us back to the Commission. But in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build do not have the opportunity to live in different countries or establish relationships as a result of the heavy tax burden that can arise from the lack of fiscal harmonization.
fiscal. Can the Council do something to help us break out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the titular holder is not here, that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a European parliamentarian.
And as a European parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European parliamentarians have with regard to the application of Community Law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to pick on the Commission. I think we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is, the Commission has only a few officials at its headquarters, where some complaints reach it and it has some possibilities for action. But, at the moment, there is also a tendency to limit budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here, in this respect, I don't think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is help the Commission, and I believe that Mrs. Frassoni's report contains some points that could be useful in achieving this implementation.
I am referring to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission that was led by my colleague from the group present here, Marián, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and to be present in this Tribunal and to be aware of the immense work that this Tribunal was carrying out, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been mentioned here, has set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the Resolution rightly points out, it is the first international tribunal financed by voluntary contributions, it is the first tribunal to be established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first tribunal, as has already been mentioned, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other tribunals that have been established in its wake, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we consider it essential that this Resolution be approved, on which we have been working together with the Tribunal for several months now.
Two years ago we passed a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago the Tribunal was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of...
The Tribunal was short of money and did not have enough support. We must also thank the European Commission for coming to the aid, shall we say, financial, of this Tribunal.

Now we are asking, above all, for two things first, that the convicted individuals serve their sentences. At stake is not the functioning of the Tribunal, which will end next year, but the legacy that this Tribunal will leave us. Secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
Ultimately, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the Court, we saw a motto written that was "Without justice, there is no peace."
And precisely for that reason we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans, but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this Tribunal remains permanent in history.

Mr President, very briefly, which I am sure you will appreciate at this time, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, thank you very much once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did with the third package.

maritime, that his drive, his political standing, has been able to push through an agreement close to the Council and make it possible for Parliament, Council and Commission to reach an agreement at this stage and in these final days of the legislative term.

The third maritime package is a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in all three institutions and once again justifies the codecision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in the interests of all European Union citizens.
I needed a minute before I wanted to respond to the Commissioner who knows about my friendship and affection for her and, indeed, my friendship and affection for Mr. Orban.
But the commissioner has not said a single word about the ombudsman's recommendation.

Despite all of that, and since the Ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends that the rule be changed, it does not tell us whether the Commission will take on board what the Ombudsman is asking for and what Parliament recommends based on what the Ombudsman has requested.
Mr President, I believe that the proposed regulations submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the

The European Parliament insisted on the principles that have been emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, both Mr. Svieska and Mr. Depré, and that is the principle of community competence.
This is a matter of Community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain powers of the States, but, as Mr. Barró said, limited in terms of scope and time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to renounce these community competences.

That being said, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, we can make progress in the future, starting from this point, in developing a genuine European private law, which is becoming increasingly necessary, as Mr. Sogor pointed out, for example, in the last speech.

We are talking about the problems that directly affect people the most, and to the extent that we are able to solve these people's problems, people will realize that the European Union has a role to play.
In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr Debrey and Mr Svieska, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this issue.
Madam President, Commissioner, I signed this Resolution and asked to speak on this matter because I witnessed the so-called expulsion, which was actually the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

In addition, I was able to confirm that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of the aggressor, threats, disregard for people's dignity, and the trivial use of justice are common practices in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not cited.

such as the case of Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and, in addition, because it voted for a mayor who was not part of the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others and, specifically, Citibank, and managed to found his own business, Banco de Caracas. Moreover, he later lived a normal life helping those most in need.
Today, however, he is illegally imprisoned in a Caracas jail, two years after being detained without any coherent charges.
Their only crime is being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nilson Moreno, a student leader at the University of Los Andes, who was elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 elections to the federation, is currently Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is charged with manslaughter, in a state of frustration, violent lascivious acts, and all that despite having been exonerated of these charges.

Situations like hers are everyday life in this country, where the persecution of adversaries with the intention of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent have become part of daily life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be deposed at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and is burning more and more.
That is why the Resolution approved by this Parliament cannot be just another Resolution that serves to highlight the great concern we feel for the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for one reason or another, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some states or autonomous communities, the fact is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, at its disposal.
Neither the victims, nor the damage suffered, nor the need for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budget cycles.

We must prioritize and we must act, and acting is, in this case, modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them and coordinating preventive policies in an optimal manner, demanding when the time comes.

case, responsibilities to states that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem of some southern European states and that climate change does not only affect some states, it affects everyone and is a common cause.

round to minimize greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because, obviously, they are at the root of fires, of their causes, and these, in turn, are at the root of more climate change.
