Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I am addressing Mr Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and respect for a long time, ever since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear to us, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have absolutely taken me by surprise now.

I am surprised for two reasons: firstly, because you have shown contempt for the Group in which I am present, the Non-attached Group, not considering us worthy of even a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have shown contempt for all our constituents.
Secondly, because of the fragility of their political project, because of the poverty of their political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission".
proposals that do not even manage to incorporate what you have defended throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
I have been surprised, in this regard, that issues such as energy, which have been well managed throughout his term, are now, when he offers us his...

Commissioner, you ended your speech by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began it by telling us that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to err is human, to correct is divine.
And that is a Spanish saying that could very well apply to the case at hand today.

The dairy sector has been suffering from one of the most serious crises in its history for months, and despite this, because you are unwilling to compromise, the European Commission and some governments, including my own, the Spanish government, refuse to back down from the decisions made during the CAP health check.
Such decisions were made without taking into account the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It feels as though the member states either did not want to or were unable to see the storm brewing at that time.
The reform quickly became outdated due to the significant shift in the market, a shift that demonstrates that the sector is entirely at the mercy of price volatility.

The fact that major producers like France and Germany, countries that achieved the largest increase in their national production quotas in absolute terms in that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the checkpoint decisions, is very thought-provoking.

In my view, the Member States were wrong and should have listened more carefully to the voices, including mine, that called for postponing any definitive decisions about the future of the sector until 2011.
It's a shame they didn't listen to us.
They will listen. Do it now.
Mr President, this Parliament is the Palace of the Chimera, it is the Palace of Dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, gives us encouragement and strength to continue prospering and building a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way, only in this way would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the founding fathers of Europe, thanks to whose work we are all here.

Mr President, having overcome the concerns generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my opinion, to consider how to deal with nationalist attitudes in the future, which so hinder the construction of Europe.
My idea is that these obstacles cannot come free of charge.
With a clear head, it is time to think about the possible measures to be adopted in the coming days and years.
This modest MP wants a future Council President who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, who will manage the...
euro, which is in the Schengen area and is identified with and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr President.
That is, on behalf of the Commission, I would have had nothing more to add but an amen, but I had already prepared the speech on behalf of the Socialist Group.
The breakdown of constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a dangerous precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, such as Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and dumb in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation, in line with the position unanimously adopted by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president Michelete has broken the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing the return, among other measures, of the rightful president, Mr. Celaya.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29 suffers from illegitimacy from the outset, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would make a serious mistake if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, because this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is accredited for being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.
As Vaclav Havel said this morning, there cannot be two sets of weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, therefore, fighters for freedom. And therefore, whether we are talking about Cuba, China, North Korea or now Honduras, our discourse must be firm in the face of those who destroy freedom.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preference.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup leaders or dictators, only freedom killers and oppressors.
Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change and that a very dangerous precedent will have been set, and the doctrine of the good, temporary, and not too cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr President, I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Committee and its Chairman, Mr Leinen, for the work they have done so that we can have a Resolution like the one we have and which we must approve without hesitation.
We cannot be satisfied with talking about having enough sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting part of the failure.
We have decided to approve this Resolution which has three noble aspirations.
One more obvious one is to avoid climate change with concrete proposals for emission reduction and a commitment to funding, and aiming for a binding agreement, not piecemeal ones.

and two latent aspirations: one, to start working sooner rather than later on establishing a common energy policy, just as we once created a common agricultural policy because it was necessary; and the other, which is of course also included, is to regain the trust of citizens in politics and in politicians, which is something we have more than enough of in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the Summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the acting president of the Council to continue with his optimism, to push and negotiate all he can to drag the others into this success.

I don't know if the rulers of this multipolar world want to be judged by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a deputy, and I believe all representatives of the peoples, cannot be judged by history for not being able in Copenhagen to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity to avoid climate change.

Today, there is no doubt about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism and, thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice and security that is so necessary.

But, in my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust between the member states, but it is high time, with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations in the direction of not prescribing terrorist crimes, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening, and may continue to happen, causing consequent harm to the victims of terrorism, who see those who murdered their loved ones being treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr President, I would firstly like to congratulate Mrs McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in meeting international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the Community budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be, and in past decades it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to run his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction for the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to reestablishing a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships between the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with products from third countries, where much lower standards are applied for these imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply the markets in their own countries for a genuine matter of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 around 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the European Union's action is primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand by indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request that assistance to victims be unconditional, more decisive, and with harsher penalties, as Mr. Barrott has just told us.
That being said, I would like to ask the President and the Council to use all the European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency to ensure that this order provides victims with special protection measures that are effective throughout the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely serious problem of human trafficking, and that we will not just stop at empty words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard like myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your role as President-in-Office of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges in this period, and of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations that have been created.
so that the public can see that our renewed institutions are a tool capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But we have put it in, because your lordship knows that it is shared by us.
For the Popular Party of Spain, this is a matter of state, and we will support your lordship in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that are important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program and one that, hopefully, will be filled with content.

I would like for people to be able to see in that album of the Spanish Presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, that they see in each event a milestone on real issues that affect them.
The crisis hits economies and unemployment seems like a fifth horse of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that twenty percent of unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it forces us all to produce a solution to a problem that we really have to solve together.
That was a real problem.
Time does not allow me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead, and I believe, I am confident in Spain's capabilities as a nation, and I want to believe and I am sure that you will be up to the level of our country.

We cannot fail to meet these expectations at this hour for Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world, which has been addressed with intelligence, is giving rise to new centers of power, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should hand us the ability to make proposals.
We have that legitimacy.
What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Don Quixote received from Sancho when he recommended humility in the daydreaming about governing the Barataria island.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly equal government and the courageous way in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action programme, of course, against gender violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender Violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
you can count on our solidarity
solidarity of women with Zapatero.
Mr. President, on a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to take action.
We should anticipate this, but we don't.
And, unfortunately, we move forward through attacks like the failed Detroit attack, which today forces us to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding about body scanners at airports is a responsibility we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting because the terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Having guaranteed this, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I say that there is no higher right than the right to live. And those of us who love freedom above all else need to live in safety in order to feel truly free.
Mr President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with determination and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improve coordination" should be abandoned, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and ultimately refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as there is no progress towards European financial integration and there are no Eurobond issues.

In any case, the European institutions can already take concrete actions. I won't insist on the rhetoric of coordination. And there is, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wanted to say that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law on abortion in Spain.

What concerns me is human life, and I am concerned above all else, and I am here to defend women whose lives are in danger due to gender violence and to offer them a space in which they can live freely and safely.

The Resolution of this Parliament of February 2, 2006, recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established an area of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens and prioritised the fight against gender violence.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency to promote a European protection order for victims of gender violence during its term, to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender violence should also have no borders, and the member states should make an effort to harmonize their legislation so that the idea of fighting against the mistreatment of women transcends...

legislative obstacles and in the end we could offer, at least within the European Union, we could protect the lives of women and their children. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to do everything possible.

It is necessary and everything that is in their power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live free and safe.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which had such an impact and inspired so much hope among the peoples of the world, especially among the most brilliant international youth.
What characterizes, however, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers at this moment is the impiety towards political and prisoners of conscience, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco the Moribund, with his mistreatment of political prisoners, whom he also considered common, his same obsessive contempt for the exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco and all the enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and show solidarity with those who are struggling and suffering.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who destroy freedoms.

Let us never again allow a person who was fighting for their rights and those of everyone else to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our raising our voice loud and clear demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old black construction worker, who only asked for improved prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
and in those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and reviled by his jailers, amidst a thick silence from the international community, which must be remembered.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Ladies and gentlemen, the resolution that we are presenting today, debating today, and voting on tomorrow, which I am representing on behalf of the Social Democrat Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
once again, it speaks out in favor of a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not, for the moment, enter into a topic that divides us on whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let's focus on the topic now of saving lives and human rights.
and let us open a period of serene reflection in which we seek common ground on the issues of future policy with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that six political groups are presenting it expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

that it will never again be claimed that the European democratic right bends to the so-called orders of Yankee imperialism, but that it will also never again be said that the social democrats are complacent or are accomplices to the communist dictatorship.
Simply because both statements are false and the victims of the freedom killers, wherever they are, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.
Mr President, I would finally like to thank Mr Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs Weber of the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, Mr

Thank you, Mrs. Romeva, on behalf of the Greens, to Mr. Kasutnik, of the Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

Finally, I also want to thank the President of the Spanish Government and the President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for their encouragement and support in getting this Resolution that we are debating today off the ground.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer who moved his people to tears.
History effectively absolves him of his rebellion against tyranny and then against the American blockade.
But with the same emphatic judgment, this Parliament, which represents the greatest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that...
The people of Cuba suffer from the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, and the contempt for their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, deputies of all ideologies stand by the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible means must be used to prevent the brutal repression they are suffering, even by going beyond the paralyzing Common Position.
I pay homage to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Stay calm, comrades.
We're leaving now.
This week marked International Women's Day.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, violence against women can be ended.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to me to acknowledge that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the military or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, so far the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, which is why it is correct to speak of almost absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat femicides - a harsh but accurate term when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, only eleven of the criminals who murdered nearly seven hundred women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and even
now more than three years in jail for looting Erasolitas during an incident in a market, six men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
investigation. I hope the judge, who will decide in a week about the appeal in this case, realizes the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules operational are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Moreover, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a primary concern in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do tonight is to thank Mr. Escotá for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a real pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated in the vote tomorrow in this European Parliament and we are proud of a position like this, which defends quality, which bets on the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as...

not mere testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as true agents generating wealth and employment, employment that we so desperately need now in these times of economic crisis and dramatic situation in employment levels in some Member States.

We also appreciate the defense maintained by this European Parliament and the position held by the Committee on Agriculture, which has made it clear that it is committed to quality in its highest degree.
And at that maximum level, we are, of course, committed to maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course we reject the idea of lowering quality and we want attention to be paid to, and value to be placed on, community production.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
which, of course, was a pleasure to hear him talk about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
Of course we hope that he will listen to the voice of this Parliament that will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And finally, I want to say that we hope that it will never happen again that the European Commission gets ahead of this Parliament by prohibiting things like, for example, the marketing standards for fruits and vegetables that have done so much damage to free competition in Europe.
We want market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to focus on quality, variety, food safety and an adequate quantity of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of these community agri-food productions to be defended in the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also have the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our European producers and consumers cannot continue to be defenseless.
Mr President, the Commissioner spoke about the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, therefore, be consistent.
We have missed too many opportunities, too many treaties, to introduce Community competence over European airspace.

for example, by monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts in land transport

which was a mandate that was already in the Rome Treaties. That is why, the coordinators - and I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr. Jauregui and Mr. Duff - have agreed on an amendment.

2. Tomorrow we will vote, and I hope that this House will support it, precisely so that this issue, this question of a uniform electoral procedure for the European Parliament elections, can be resolved soon.
I think that would eliminate this type of question.

In his speech, Mr. Traskowski spoke about the necessary representativeness of this Chamber, and this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice President Shevkovich, among others, have highlighted.
I agree and we say in the report of article one that the eighteen enter as a block because if it were not so, we would lose representativeness.

And in order for them to enter en masse, in order to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, Your Excellency, be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional solutions.

And that is why I do not hide it. I do not like the possibility that this Chamber will have deputies who have not been elected in the 2009 elections. I say this very clearly in paragraph two. But if I have to choose between that and not having any...

between eighteen or seek a pragmatic solution and that we reach eighteen and therefore comply with the Lisbon Agreement, I ask this House, and hence my report, to opt for that transitional, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, a fair one.
Thank you very much to all for your collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so last March 11, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like today from this Parliament to pay them a well-deserved tribute that recognizes the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.

It is high time that these European institutions recognized the dignity of the victims of terrorism and helped them in their right to protection and justice, and that this be translated into law soon.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article will be that support for the victims of terrorism will be recognized as the right to justice and that no government will ever pay a political price.

I appeal to all those who can defend the victims to never forget that true peace is born from justice, and that is the only one that we who believe in justice must defend from Europe and from anywhere in the world.

It has been necessary, Mr President, to face the abyss and the economic collapse for the heads of state and government to understand that the path forward is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
Measures such as the decline of the veto right in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasure are circulating in this direction.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government, because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what is lacking is authentic government if we want to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must push for all those reforms that aim to strengthen Europe and make budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, of course, about nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only correct recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of the INTA Committee, we would like to thank Mrs de Sarnez for the cooperation we have received.
Today, more than ever, there is a need for unity around the Mediterranean, the strengthening of major projects, and institutional development.
Today, more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models and to sustainable development.

The Barcelona summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new joint venture, democratization, and economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.

For Spain, this is vital because this axis is a priority, as it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
without excluding other priority routes, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.

This is one of the two conditions.
the possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean area was opened up.

Therefore, if we increase the topic of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this minute to congratulate the Spanish rotating presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the...
common position with regard to Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that includes, of course, as a priority issue, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency in January.
This year, with the expulsion of the deputy speaking to you, when he was trying to visit, with all the visas and all the legality, the island to concern himself with human rights there.

Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation that is of paramount importance for consumers and for the agri-food industry, because it is not easy at all to achieve balanced labelling that contains all the essentials, but is not so exhaustive that it complicates the information.
This is a great report and the rapporteur should be congratulated on it.
I agree with her on the major issues relating to nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not comply with the
commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation 19/24/2006.

There is one issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of the coexistence of national rules for labeling, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a true single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it could mislead the consumer.
In addition, voluntary labeling is always expected to be available.
Going further can complicate things, can involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any clear significant benefit to the consumer.
And regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal is in line with the existing Directive, which has worked well and has not caused any problems.
And reopening this debate can be dangerous and unnecessary, and cause problems for the circulation of products.
Mr. President, the best proof of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the plenary.

But, in addition to good intentions, I believe we must be practical when it comes to labeling food, if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing, that is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to inform themselves.
It's not about illustrating, but about preventing, about informing them about what they can eat and to what extent.
measure. We need to label fats, sugars, and trans fats.
Indeed.
effectively on what affects cholesterol, especially those substances that affect what we have mentioned: obesity and people's health.

Yes, but some other foods with some other information such as the place of origin when it does not lead to confusion or, for example, in a piece of meat, stating the place of birth, the place of transit, the place of grazing, the place of sacrifice of the cow can be very illustrative, but they will end up causing confusion.

It is up to us to be practical and ensure that this regulation remains as the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, if not, as the one that will cause more confusion and impose issues that, far from achieving better health rates, will result in greater degrees of confusion.

That's why I ask, for example, that some opt for the GDA, the daily intake amount, instead of the traffic lights, because it's very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you'll get fat, so only consume one.
The amount of daily intake versus other types of codes is what we propose for some, so as not to further confuse the consumer.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency for a report like this, Commissioner.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on your ability to reach a common agreement and to bring all interests together, resulting in an own-initiative report, one of the first own-initiative reports.
The development of aquaculture is important.

This is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity. But I want to emphasize at this time the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates jobs.
Health guarantees are important, sustainability is important, and the protection of the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture and also the scientific and research sector need to be enhanced.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fraguero said, within the CFP, as the Commissioner said.

We need to give it a coherent framework for coordination, we need to give it the possibility to regularize itself, because aquaculture can mean sufficiency, sustainability and economic resources, and I think it is important for Europe.
Mr President, in my opinion this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new Transport White Paper, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

The present report highlights several key points: the need for a financial fund as an indispensable tool, the challenge of the increasing demand for freight transport, and the search for multimodal solutions that

provide safety for users and goods the urgent need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport the diagnosis, in my opinion, is accurate that mere competition between the different ones should not be allowed

modes, but rather complement each other by seeking criteria of efficiency. The speaker's assertion, which I consider to be both courageous and fair, that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
