It is a mistake in approach, Mr. President.
Did you think you were really going to preside over Europe and influence the gears that make the complex European machinery run?
He even came to believe, and allowed people close to him to proclaim, that the world would experience a stellar moment under his presidency.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let's go into some specifics.

In these six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between the political direction of the Presidency and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been working in the engine rooms.
The first one has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the Presidency of the Government, which has been more of a back-and-forth affair.
However, I want to highlight the effort of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And the fact is, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is something to be lamented, it is that they are too often marginalized in daily reality.
That being said, it should be acknowledged that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 Strategy and, above all, those concerning the European External Action Service, have remained more in the air, both still being too fragile.
What has happened with the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender Violence has been lamentable, and the same dismal outcome has been offered by the
a basic Community patent for the survival of thousands of companies and partly blocked by the linguistic problems that Spanish legislation encourages.

But all the major political initiatives have ended in spectacular failure, from the Mediterranean Summit to the EU-US Summit, the latter of which was marked by the fact that his own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must agree that the inability to implement its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the progress made towards better European economic governance cannot, in any way, be attributed to his Presidency, which was conspicuously absent from the most relevant issues.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

I do want to draw one positive conclusion from this experience: my fantasy as a convinced Europeanist is excited at the thought that it could mean the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived up to now.

Would this be good news? Well, as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being submerged in the void of irrelevance.
Mr President, believe me, Mr Zapatero, I would have liked to have delivered a different speech today.
He set, your honor, a semester full of ambition and set the bar so high in his aspirations that, when comparing it to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The fact is that his lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation that required leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has once remarked that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was up to you, sir, to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain who were urgently demanding the fulfillment of their obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements that have not been lacking have been obscured.
Your Lordship has had time to recount them, I have not.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what it appears to be. Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit, and the announced European Union and United States partnership are all significant failures.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not enhanced the image of Spanish management, as the way of achieving any respectable goal has been labeled as shoddy.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be so, despite the mismanagement of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained their composure and, thanks to this, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the judgment of this Presidency will be more influenced by the situation in Spain than by what has or has not been done here.
It was hardly possible for someone who has placed their country in a state of uncertainty and unease to lead such a difficult company.
At best, this presidency has been sadly irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will fully enter into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency will achieve what the Spanish Presidency has not managed to do, namely to steer the discussions in such a way that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

a truly strong common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the twenty-seven Member States, both new and old, and not what happened in 2005, when there was a lack of money and modulation had to be invented.

The next reform of the CAP will determine the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services such as environmental care, but should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, so it is necessary for the European Parliament to ensure security and supply based on community production as the main objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and comes at a good time, because it has demonstrated the abuses committed by large-scale distribution by severely disrupting the various links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which may at times go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must be recognized from the perspective of a social market economy, such as the one advocated by the European People's Party. I must say, it does address the legitimate demands of European producers.

Moreover, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always a good thing, and gives much more scope and support for the weaker sectors of that chain to defend themselves, and of course supports European consumers in learning more about that chain.

The European food industry could have been given more consideration in this report, perhaps, and it would have been very good, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also included to ensure fairness for these links in the chain, as requested by the Committee on the Environment, and there is also a call to combat the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to strictly prohibit them.
It is also important to include measures to prevent unfair practices through white labels that are against competition and that violate intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, we must support the Bové report and support all our colleagues who, from the different parliamentary committees INCO, ENVI or Agriculture, have shown that they are working hard to ensure that this report finally comes to light and helps European producers to get ahead.
the alarm bell rings and it is true.
And there is also frustration, as can be heard in the speeches in this plenary session, for not having achieved the millennium goals.
And the truth is that what is at stake is very much.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided not to continue eating the small fish, we would have to pay for everything out of pocket, with our health and well-being as the currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering and conservation measures.

But, as the unmet targets demonstrate, it seems as though there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination that have also been mentioned here, but also for expansion beyond our extremely limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked away in a ghetto area, as sometimes seems to be done, with a glance from time to time.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders; it crosses the entire Earth in a domino effect where if one piece falls, all the others fall.

And I draw attention to the need for a global and more community-based approach, especially with regard to soil, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for managing soil or forests, can be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be cast, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soil would help to conserve the entire territory.

Europe is so varied, so diverse for good and for bad, and so lacking in political will on the part of the states, and so in need of more and more European Union, in the fullest sense of the word, and what that means is more union for the land as well.

Mr President and Commissioner, first of all I want to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs Macabena, not only in terms of content, but also in terms of form, because she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We would also like to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this Agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of the safety of marketed drugs, especially in relation to their risk profiles and potential adverse reactions.

It is worth noting the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

The solution reached for the notification to Eudravigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by the Member States and by those responsible for the marketing of medicinal products, is very important.

Eudravigilance will be the only source of information, but simultaneously the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed, and this is very important.
It is also worth noting the opportunity it provides consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the Agency's creation and management of a portal.
The European Medicines Safety Portal, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help to improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.
And, finally, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in protecting public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this, by improving not only the current procedures, but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.

Mr. President, I greatly appreciate the opponent's effort to accept some suggestions and, of course, their defense of copyright, which I share. However, the inclusion of the infringing and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the

The recognition of sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the alternative resolution excluding mass exchanges as a possible infringement, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports on the list.
The Galó report has aroused great interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too heatedly centered around the argument for or against the so-called French law.
Adopi, an Internet disconnection measure for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other progress in national legislation.

I hope we will reach a common position within the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposed Directive that will soon arrive in Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.
On that occasion, we will try to reach a more balanced position than today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
Mr President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the Members of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been missed, in part, to strengthen Europe's common institutions, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence.
limited compared to similar authorities in Member States and it is also regrettable that no progress has been made towards a similar integration to that which occurred with the central bank system.
We have made progress, but we must continue to climb the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the ETA terrorist organization murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I am addressing this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for allowing terrorists from

they are trained in Venezuelan sleep under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubillas, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the fact that an international arrest warrant is out for him, which is a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Government of Spain take decisive action in the face of this grave humiliation of all Spaniards.
Zapatero cannot continue to remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our civil guards torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
nor can we look the other way in the face of this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give it the response it deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that the intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then we have been trying to resolve this issue.
We haven't managed to do it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, have to meet on a date that is not suitable.
they almost never have meeting rooms and they never have interpretation.

Today I speak not only as president of the Intergroup on Poverty and Human Rights, but with the mandate of most of the intergroups in this House, and therefore of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
and I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and overturn the decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of freedom for the intergroups.
And if it does not, I also say politely that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this House and it will decide who in this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, the International Day against Human Trafficking and Exploitation brought to light some data that should prompt us to act immediately.
More than ninety percent of the prostitution practiced in Europe comes from blackmail and extortion.

And in light of these facts, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and promoting support plans for female victims.
but it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next Directive on Combating is an opportunity to address the demand through education and make it more difficult to access, for example, by offering advertising opportunities in all types of media, in addition to increasing bilateral cooperation with third countries to combat this scourge at its source.
we have an opportunity
I draw the attention of this Parliament to continue being at the forefront of citizens' rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the foreign service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because now is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or retained in the short term, or for wars between the different European institutions.
What is needed now, on the contrary, is to have an overall vision of what the European Union should be in the world, that is, to do just the opposite of what
which happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices were heard, not all of them courageous, coming from Europe.
One of the exceptions to note is the President of this Parliament, Mr. Butchek, who is the author of a brilliant and dignified statement.

Mr. President, the Regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of cutlery and related products, which in my region, the Land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of more than eight thousand jobs, an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a source of employment.
And the Medin seal on knives has long been advocated by social groups such as Aprecu and fought for by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to transparency, fair trade rules, and the fight against unfair competition.

It is about increasing consumers' decision-making capacity when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of the product, but also the quality brand, the place of origin, or the social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are going through a tough time, but who today look at us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for fairer trade, yes, but also for adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
That is why I am grateful to the opponent and to Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my land.
Mr. President, let's see if I can bring a bit of calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some countries and some of the states that make up the European Union are still present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there were at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what would, in my opinion, be that common position?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a comprehensive agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for

avoid the turbulence in the markets from dragging us along and making us repeat the mistakes that were made throughout the 20th century. The euro, in third place, must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public
In summary, it is important to know that in the global world, in this global game, those who only play national cards lose.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we are in a position to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Meissner.
There were differing positions found and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.

Ladies and gentlemen, the Transport Committee has decided that all bars should be protected in a similar manner, and to justify this, they argue that if this were not the case, it would lead to an unfair competition situation.

We accept the majority position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I would not hesitate to point out to the House that it also implies a certain lack of fairness.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that controls on sulphur limit values will have to be more stringent in these cases.
The measures concerning ports should be positively evaluated in terms of their impact on solutions to reduce transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that we still have work to do on this issue.
If we do not commit to a decisive liberalization of the ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they should play in the context of comodality.
Welcome also, ladies and gentlemen, is the impetus of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change.
I think this is a positive report that we should vote for.
But we must not forget that it occurs in the context of a major disaster, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

And in this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework of the revision of the Regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency strengthens the role that the Agency should play in the prevention inspections and subsequent tasks of cleaning up oil spills.
My personal judgment, Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks should be reinforced with the mandate that is required for this purpose.
Mr President, the integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and agriculture, and it must not be subordinated to other policies.

We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both to society in general and to the fishing industry. New technologies, fishing methods, species development, a plan for maritime economy.

for more, better and higher employment, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and to promote the governance of our barrier-free seas and not have sustainability problems, as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy, this would be working towards the environment and sustainability.
Mr. President, the Church of Our Lady of Help was recently attacked in Baghdad, and fifty-eight people, mostly women and children, were murdered simply because they were Christians.
Al-Qaeda has proudly claimed authorship of the massacre.
It is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks on Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Busek has made an institutional statement.
The statement of condemnation by the High Representative, Mrs. Ashton, was limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
terrorist. Why isn't the motive cited? The condition of the Christians, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I haven't heard anything from Mr. Zapatero, I haven't heard anything from President Erdogan.
Erdogan, what is the purpose of the alliance of civilizations?
I feel sorry for our foolishness and our cowardice.

Inevitably, the memory comes to mind of the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Thank you also to the Commissioner. I share the desire of this House.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to get the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is important to emphasize the role of cities in environmental preservation.

There is an agreement between more than zero mayors of the European Union that demonstrates the existence of recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are crucial if we want to succeed.
The grand words we use are of no use if we do not have the cooperation of the mayors of the cities.
It is therefore very important that emissions are disclosed, as cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, and, even worse, there is no common standard for measuring these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project, which already hosts information from thousands of companies and which I think could also be used by municipalities.
Without their cooperation, without the cooperation of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action remains nothing but smoke, the very smoke we want to escape from.

Mr President, some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient, given the scale of the repression of human rights in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or any legal title.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate his violence.
Yesterday I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, I hope will prevent that of Western Sahara, and that we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague, as I said, but this time for war crimes.
Mr President, Commissioner, the Directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing safety in toys.
It's a big step in the right direction because it shows us the way forward, but it's not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered to be CMR toxic, fragrances, or other hazardous substances such as HPA compounds.
The rules to be followed need to be clearer about the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances, supported by solid studies, and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between member states and rely on the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are getting ready to do their holiday shopping, and we must give them the assurance that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
I believe that in this debate we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder, what obstacle exists in approving this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there that something so necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe will finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
we have overcome the legal obstacles in our negotiations and I applaud the Commission for recognizing our work, just as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

We do not have to exclude ourselves, but rather help each other by approving this more concrete instrument today, and tomorrow the broader package of measures to aid the victims that the Commission will present, and with which I commit to collaborating.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women or children.
Let us help those who are looking to us today for a better life, a life that will return to them their freedom, their security, and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the Group of the European People's Party will vote enthusiastically for this report, and my congratulations first to the rapporteurs, the Commission and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, the term "democratic deficit" in the 1980s.
With this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were only made by the Council of Ministers on the proposal of the Commission, and this Parliament was only consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, the Lisbon Treaty, has been

fill that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of the National Parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we rounded it off today with this citizens' legislative initiative, which was due, in the work of the Convention, to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I want to remember here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German Social Democrat colleague, and Alain Lamassoure, who brought that initiative to the Convention's plenary session and ensured that it was approved.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have drawn up, put on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us as a responsible Parliament and a Parliament with codecision powers.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
Mr President, in January 2012, four hundred Spanish egg producers could disappear, around thirty percent of the total in my country, with the loss of three hundred thousand tons of eggs.

And the European Union could stop producing those eighty million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only manage to have them covered by imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.
This directive from 1999, which requires an increase in the space of cages for laying hens, demands that we act with intelligence and a feasible vision, because if we don't.

we will only manage to weaken European production and give extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than the current space we have in the European Union.

It is a Directive that requires a huge effort from European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost rises to around six hundred million euros, but it must also be remembered that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproducts industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of the honourable Members for the amendment proposed by the Popular Group to the second paragraph, which calls for a solution to be sought, at least, for those responsible industrial farms that are in the process of transforming their operations and will have almost completed them by January 2012.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a sudden shortage in the community market, which would consequently increase prices for consumers.
It is about respecting the Directive, giving a chance to the egg and egg product industry, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs Grosset and Mrs Dagmar Ronberend from my own group, for the work they have done to get a regulation out of deadlock and make it useful, because this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that must guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at any given moment, especially because it also allows for clear regulation of the role of states, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but rather that this should be the beginning of a much greater advancement that makes, as Mrs. Romperen said, of this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all the States makes it unnecessary for each citizen to travel to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees citizens' rights more effectively in relation to the care they must receive, benefits, accessibility, and security, rather than the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will make Union work, or else we will be taking very small steps.
Madam President, the Spanish Socialist Delegation has voted in favour, like the rest of our group, but I would not leave here without expressing my concern, because this Directive includes
the issue of organ transplants against the opinion of the Committee on the Environment as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this very plenary, both with the Transplant Directive and with the Action Plan, just a short time ago and with virtually unanimous support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that the good work done by such successful organizations as the National Transplant Organization of Spain is not diminished by this inclusion, and certainly not with the intention of saving twenty zero lives that we had in both the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and say that we will continue to monitor compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data is alarming. The World Health Organization estimates that more than three hundred million people contract a sexually transmitted disease involuntarily each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, there is a worrying increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers due to an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Moreover, as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe regarding access to sexual health services, depending on the country and, within these countries, depending on the citizens' income level.
A European strategy is needed to combat all of this.
Only five member states have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted disease infections, and also the number of abortions has been reduced.
A common strategy that focuses on prevention in the educational field, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
a comprehensive and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of every citizen to sexual health under the best conditions of safety and hygiene.
In a moment of strong social tensions, one cannot help but enthusiastically welcome the great social agreement in Spain between the government, unions, and employers' associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been achieved for a long time.

the arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, should also be taken into account, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8.
Cándido then insisted on the need to extend collective bargaining on a European scale and on the need to have the voice and initiative of trade unions in our Europe.
This is how it should be.

Mr President, while acknowledging the differences in terms of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union unfortunately operates on the basis of emergency situations, such as a serious one.

an attack or a massive landing of immigrants like the one currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia towards the Italian coasts could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our consciences, on those of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we'll put our hands over our heads, but the next day we'll forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy does not work, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient financial means for Frontex to be effective.
Talking costs nothing, but we have to act.
Do they really believe that Frontex can currently guarantee the security of European borders?
I don't think so.

And let's hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather to do so in their own countries, because that is what they have been fighting for, and we must help them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth when discussing a common European migration policy, which is more necessary today than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is noteworthy that in OECD countries, the highest levels of equity in citizens' income are found in pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost twenty percent of their value in 2008 alone, and that they are still far from the required solvency levels today.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a cross-cutting manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.
ambitious policies on access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also ensure, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of scholarships in companies, since, as a general rule, these are excluded from all types of social contributions.
In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers who, if they are being asked to do more to have a decent pension, should also be made to suffer less to access decent work.

Mr President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories so that their citizens can make the most of their territorial distinctiveness.
But, in order to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that are facing the same challenges and problems.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union Strategy for the Atlantic region: a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states in the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary that this strategy be based on renewed multi-level governance, based on closer participation of public authorities.
regional and local authorities, Member States, the European Union and private sector stakeholders and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who fought a hundred years ago for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have made great progress in these hundred years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and discrimination against women is a reality.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this Women's Day, to show my support and hope to all the women in the North African Revolution who are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman is not worth half a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are worth the same and deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many people do not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half of what men do, and that domestic violence primarily affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament and, of course, I promise that I will continue to work.
Mr President, I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the Members who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest vote in favor will depend on the European Council's willingness to admit the role of the aforementioned institutions.
because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of economic governance led by a European Union
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, we must avoid at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental route, which is a dead end or the route of the predominance of a few States, because all of this would thwart the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of the stones that reinforce and balance this delicate edifice.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to the Commission.
The parliamentary journey of this report does not end here, however.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both national and European level.
And, in particular, my esteem for the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacio Alonso.
we have succeeded in having the general principle of maximum harmonisation of the old Article Four rejected.

It must be said very loudly that maximum harmonization, by establishing the same protection in all Member States, would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, since there is a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights in various countries.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of unfair contractual terms is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of terms it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

reverse the burden of proof for individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who have to demonstrate that clauses deviating from the generally established terms have been negotiated individually, that contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and comprehensible manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonisation in relation to unfair terms.
The Eurobarometer tells us that 79% of traders believe that full harmonisation in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr President, Commissioner, allow me first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Schwab and Mrs Gerhardt on the excellent work they have done.
and a general reflection.
It's not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that it's about not cutting rights that already exist in some of the member states.
Because, if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
establish a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to emphasize that the rights that have been established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis and that, furthermore, either we are not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on everyone to make a small gesture towards sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off their lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow their lead.
but it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are distant or insecure.
We need to help states build a new energy model in which renewable energies are at the heart of the new one.
And we must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to appeal to all the countries of the Union to join that call, to that will of five of their States, including Spain, to increase the reductions of CO2 emissions by thirty percent, because in this way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also at the forefront of its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and I am here again to fight against it.

I must say that not only do I not tire of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a sounding board, and this Parliament is the best one.

I am a spokesperson available to defend all those women who suffer abuse daily and who need us, legislators, to pressure states to punish the aggressors according to the severity of the crime, and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives and that children have also suffered to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, such as that recognized by the Commission in its Action Plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting time and time again on protecting victims, as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, of which I was the rapporteur and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that, when it comes to addressing domestic violence, which affects all members of the family,
Families, children, the elderly, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, because we are all honored to make progress in solving this social scourge.

The first thing is not to remain silent and the second thing is to get to work, because, although we have been talking about gender violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We must be doing something wrong and, therefore, it is time to forget about demagogy and move from words to actions, providing more help and the necessary reaction so that women can live with dignity and security.
security, so that all the victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until we all manage to defeat this
a terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Mr President, Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

Because with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for more Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that generates sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, which places citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, bluetongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, also to our public health.

a disease that we were fighting against through the use of the live vaccine, which involves the creation of restricted zones for the movement of animals, because the use of these vaccines can lead to an undesired circulation of the virus in non-infected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to areas where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for farmers: the disease on the one hand, and the restrictions on the other.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disturbances that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies, which is what is truly important, for prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use and, moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, compliance with what our Treaties require, especially regarding the correlation tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into force before the summer, because with its delay we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has carried out following the complaint lodged by FEPEX, which is the Spanish Organisation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in the year two thousand and seven by OLAF, the European Union's Anti-Fraud Agency.

I believe the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the fact that the European Commission got to work a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at least as far as the tomato sector is concerned.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to address potential pitfalls that may arise from the Entry Price Regulation in force, but has also negotiated a new Agricultural Agreement with Morocco without first resolving the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and start investigating where the fraud is occurring, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without the details we have outlined being resolved.

Our goal is not to prevent the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that these agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in these agreements are respected.

As far as the new agreement with Morocco is concerned, the European fruit and vegetable sector is only asking for guarantees that the agreed measures will be effectively implemented, and this is only possible through the reform of the current entry price system.
We won't be able to have a new agreement with Morocco until we have a new system of entry prices.
we will not be able to ratify that agreement that the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to carry out these checks, it would require a significant financial effort from them, but it is also true that we have been calling for a long time for a European customs border system, similar to the one the United States has, to ensure effective control.

Mr President, Commissioner, dealing with this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal that the Commission sent to Parliament is different from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan. We understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided that they take into account the sensitivities of the.
the European industry and, in particular, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade probably cannot be addressed with the urgency that these acts require, so we must learn for the future.

Help Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not take into account the effects of the European industry in terms of the implementation deadlines for sensitive products.
it would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not coincide with the pending text scheduled to be approved by the WTO, we would be behind schedule.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think we will have to vote against it.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my speech by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
It is an agreement that we should all be pleased about, because it affects the daily lives of all citizens, but with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few points.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and uniform information.
for consumers about the components of textile products. Comprehensive information is useless if citizens are unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive step, necessary but not sufficient; we should go further and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when we go to buy a garment is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and aim for size harmonization.
Mr President, three comments on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been weak, very subdued and imprecise, and has not been able to coordinate or direct.
Third, those affected are entitled to financial compensation quickly.
But for now, I propose to this Parliament that we organize a major European gastronomy exhibition in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, based precisely on cucumbers.
We must vindicate the lost honor of cucumber producers, an expression that appeals to the German writer Heinrich Bell.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
Mr President, first of all, it is obligatory to express sincere condolences for the twenty-three victims, twenty-two of whom were in Germany and one in Sweden.
And it has to be said that this crisis is the most compelling proof that the European Union must improve, and significantly, its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The Member States involved have demonstrated slowness, inefficiency, ineffectiveness, and, at this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem is coming from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis like the current one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were previously unnecessary.

instability, unemployment, powerlessness and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, were echoing irresponsible statements from regional authorities,

German companies were very uninformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms, meanwhile the population continued to be unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should propose to ministers today, at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., that part of the two hundred million euros that exist as unused remnants of the common agricultural policy be used.
those two hundred million euros to repair as much of the damage as possible.
To do this, it is necessary to seek a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must live up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt, and from the outset, and also finance, with their own funds, their communication campaigns to re-establish the lost consumer confidence in fruit and vegetable production.

Mr President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and I hope that what is being done will prevent there being more victims and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We don't know the causes, probably, but we do know some things that we must name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister display in addressing other states with unusual frequency, if they had translated it into diligence and efficiency in coordinating, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences on a state that has been the Spanish state and on its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to family ruin for thousands of people and small entrepreneurs, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for life for the dead.
and that the control systems are reviewed.
and that accountability is demanded from Mrs. Merkel.
and that less arrogance and more diligence be demanded of him.
and that he is held responsible for some damage he has caused.
You can't ignore that Hamburg is in its prime.
He cannot ignore his responsibilities.
You can't hide behind a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage you've caused.

A little more humility, a little more good management and a little less conservatism would have been very helpful so that this crisis did not get out of hand and Spain and other farmers in the south did not have to suffer its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and demand accountability, because in Spain we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, from the Council and from the German State.
Mr President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response to this, we have been looking for a culprit, if not the cause.

The system has not worked. We have twenty-two dead, six hundred affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, invoking a precautionary principle without scientific basis—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
contaminated, were not contaminated. I repeat this because some contrary versions have been heard around here.
But to give you an idea of the importance of what these words have sparked, three hundred jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, you know that there are no borders. We are asking for accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at the moment, it has a higher number of affected people, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as we European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were exemplary farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families are asking why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not just in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will quickly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, asks for immediate and moral economic measures for all producers who, from Andalusia and from all over Europe, look at us with indignation, but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
Mrs. Merkel's treatment of the southern countries in terms of agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that, it lacks credibility. Moral.
Mr President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and some other countries share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called Eurovignette.

The coincidence is that the criticism is due to our status as peripheral countries, which in the end will be the ones to pay this unique tax that will be collected by the central European Union states.
The rationale behind the Eurovignette is riddled with contradictions, and the supporting discourse is becoming increasingly fragile.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end it is not sustainable that, in order to alleviate congestion, only high-tonnage vehicles are penalized, while passenger cars are excluded, as the old slogan of "the polluter pays" is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately only have 15% allocated to the funding of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

but as a simple recommendation, so that the Minister of Finance of the time will allocate the funds raised to the purpose that he deems most appropriate to the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The end result will be nothing other than a further burden on road freight transport, which is currently the only mode that is enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more harsh in a situation of economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new added costs.

The food crisis, which has recklessly been blamed on Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and enormous losses for those affected by the Eurovignette, namely freight transporters and farmers of high-quality crops.
Those are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish Delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in taking the chair for this session, I express my sorrow and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprun, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of eighty-seven.

At Jorges Emprun we celebrate the man who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the Nazi forces in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the most notable committed writer, a collaborator in particular of our program The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death, as his colleague and friend, and I will ask President Buzek to send a message of sincere condolences and solidarity to his family and the Spanish government, which I am sure we all share.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We can no longer close our eyes.
It is incoherent to have a single currency and at the same time lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a clear rejection of competition between the debt issuance of the States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonization of tax policies that ensure equality among citizens, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, I will be told, elementary.
But you have to repeat and repeat them because no one listens.
And precisely because we do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are upon us.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument for reducing the development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have recently associated only with tough austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of the solidarity of the European project and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy. Second, to take into account the needs and characteristics

geographical regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds so that regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding abrupt changes in the allocation of aid. And fourth, promote a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing tough budget adjustment policies.
That is why the Union's support is necessary.
I hope the Council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call on the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it has been chosen based on political criteria, which constitutes discrimination against the other cities that aspired to the title.

The president of the court said that it was chosen to support the peace process and, as far as I know, in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA that, to this day, has not abandoned its weapons and that two months ago managed to have its political arm Bildu govern, among other municipalities, that of San Sebastián.
I don't think that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will make propaganda to distribute blame between victims and murderers.
murderers, where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Certainly not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues, such as Mayor Oreja, Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself, must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of throwing away the child.
Ladies and gentlemen, can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a city free for all, let it reapply for the title, and in the meantime, let them learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided me with in drafting it.
And I say the same thing about the other fellow deputies on the Committee of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was created. There is no better way to commemorate this event than to debate energy infrastructure in Europe now.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its European Common Internal Market policy: promoting renewable energies as a means or instrument for combating climate change, ensuring supply security, and diversifying its sources.
Title 21 of the Lisbon Treaty is dedicated to energy, where the commitments I just mentioned are formulated, and it also promotes the interconnection of energy networks.
The objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we are seeing a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in southern Europe.
Europe and North Africa, with the problems arising from large-scale electricity storage, the needs for recharging electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

Therefore, in the coming years, the focus will be on advancing the determination of the necessary infrastructures, establishing the criteria that will allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b, by eliminating energy islands  
c, by ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes  
d, by arbitrating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the
authorisation and licensing procedures in the Member States, ensuring financing that attracts and boosts private investment, without prejudice to the public support that is necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
It has been believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with a consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A fundamental concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to allow the execution of the necessary works.
are currently eternalized.
and are made permanent due to the opposition of the populations to seeing towers or other types of facilities grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to early information for citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that the authorities of a state do not respond to a request within a reasonable time frame.
We are facing ambitious goals that require the cooperation of everyone.
In this sense, companies in the sector are essential, as they rightly call for a stable regulatory framework, which is the best way to ensure the financing of their efforts.
So far, the European Union's energy policy, both outside its borders and within, has lacked a decidedly European impetus.
Europe must speak with a single voice, a voice that is well audible and resonates fully in the vault of the European building, because it is from our energy fragility that we must...
summoning the strength to build an energetically solid and vigorous Europe, a worthy successor in this anniversary year of that great invention that was the ECSC, our cradle precisely.

Mr President, every time there is a compromise that allows us to move forward, we should be pleased, but I also do not believe that the compromise we have reached is such that we should die of happiness.
We must be prudent in the moments of happiness we experience.

I understand the satisfaction of many in response to this new statement from ETA, but I must remind them that we still cannot ring the bells in celebration, because to this day they have not handed over their weapons, nor have they disbanded, nor have they apologized to their victims.
It is also important for you to know that in Spain we do not have to achieve any peace between two factions because there has been no war.

My brother Alberto Jiménez Becerril, murdered by ETA in Seville along with his wife, was not coming from the war; he was going home where his three children were waiting for him, who would never see him again.
