But this Regulation, while not perfect, is a step forward, decisive and in the right direction.

Because in recent times we have all realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this game, where we are also playing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements we could and protection for our producers.

It was very necessary that we allow the obligatoriness of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defense instrument, because, of course, our producers do not start with the same negotiating strength when facing distribution, intermediaries or collectors.
there is still much to be done.
We must improve the safety nets and make them more agile and more effective.
We must strive to further integrate the sector into the value chain, ensure that there is no quota distribution, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But, without any doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many livestock farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to be able to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B. has well pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which extends quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products when the figures in the current agreement are not met, is completely nonsensical.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters reported to the Committee on Petitions, specifically of this Parliament, the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpiñán at a price lower than that set in the Agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must adhere to strict environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will mention the question of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must benefit precisely the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes a zone over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices, an agreement that fights against dumping, that does not exploit Moroccan farmers and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
It is, of course, not this agreement.

Last year, the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament requested the European Commission to modify the entry price system for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a system that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own Anti-Fraud Agency, OLAF.
they are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was included in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This, this fraud, is fixed by amending the Regulation implementing the Common Organisation of the Markets in Agricultural Products, because aligning the Customs Code does not solve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, I have been advocating within the Popular Party for the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must ensure control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the entry price system is in effect, and this system prevents national customs authorities from properly tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

Modify the Regulation implementing the CMO for agricultural products and we will have solved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European legislation prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
No written statements. Once again, dear colleagues, the debate on a summit.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, trying to create an anticipation that is getting smaller every day.
are ceasing to be credible because they are not contributing to solving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and time again.

It should be known that as long as there is no progress in political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In a telegraphic manner, two ideas: first, the need to emphasize that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is being built. The second, that the use of structural funds that are unspent be authorized immediately.
These amounts can easily allow for the fight against the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I would like to pay tribute today to all the women who, despite the significant progress we have made since that March in 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still far from being achieved.
Today women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in the rural world whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there has already been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats made by those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe it is a trend that needs to change.
I want to send a message of hope and, with many women, with the help of more and more men, we have to move forward on the path of equal opportunities, rights and also duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still much to be done.
I have to admit that I don't believe deeply and absolutely in quotas, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree with that.

I have worked with many of my colleagues and, of course, with Mrs. Reding, to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women can regain the place they deserve, and you can count on my help in this endeavor.

Mr. President, at a time of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health and in which, as in the case of the community where I live, research centers such as the Prince Felipe Center for Diabetes are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever, it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that tells the States that they have to increase research, including with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize people's health above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and implementing national programs coordinated by the Commission, while demanding results on diabetes, is a way of ensuring the quality of life of Europeans and guaranteeing their very lives.

If we allocate more money to this, some will take a little longer to collect, but those who are currently having problems will certainly have a better quality of life, and we, as States, as Council, and as Commission, will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions rights market, a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, meaning that the price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being encouraged. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques and, what is worse,
the funding of important projects, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants, will be jeopardized.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and Parliament, to conjure it up.
Mr President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun with the experience.
The cases are, however, of urgent necessity.
The deputies have verified this on the ground during a trip to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria, as well as the news that quickly reached us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Ruiz.
Tavares has fought for the European Parliament to retain the new powers gained after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, thank you very much, Commissioner, and I hope that we will also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of pushing through the asylum package next month.

The European social model that we are so proud of is not only based on our pension, education, and healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform that the Spanish government has approved without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of job quality.
Labour reform alone does not create jobs; economic growth does.
What a labor law does define, however, are the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.

And with this reform, where eighty percent of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they can be fired due to a decrease in company revenues.
they may unilaterally modify their schedules, what is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and bets on the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike like the one called for tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr President, Mr Barroso, let me begin by saying that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party finds it appropriate and endorses the two packages you have presented today, both the labour package and the solidarity aid for Greece, which is closely related to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times and events every day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
The spotlight has inevitably returned to Spain.
The alarms in the markets have been triggered without justification, fueled in part by statements that I believe, Mr. President, are inopportune.
some in the context of important elections in which both contenders cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some people, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also deal with us with little political tact.
Today here too, some have been without finesse, as the Italians would say, and there has been a lack of political delicacy.
Ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the markets does not reflect Spain's strength.
We are a solvent country with the full capacity to meet our debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Never, gentlemen from Bogota, has Mr. Rajoy said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
he said the opposite, that he is willing to meet each and every one of those objectives and reiterates it every day.

In the few months since it took office, the Spanish Government has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improved competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, as the IMF itself admitted yesterday, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures currently being taken by the Spanish government.

Other measures we have adopted include the general state budget for 2012, which in our opinion will ensure that the deficit target is met this year, and the organic law on budgetary stability, which will be passed this month.

It will present a reform in education and healthcare that will involve an adjustment of zero million euros. The reform of the financial sector will undoubtedly also contribute to financial institutions having to allocate more than fifty million euros.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

We need to save ourselves together, and Spain with everyone, without any doubt, and criticism from one side or the other does not contribute anything. Either we are all countries capable of standing together and contributing to growth and a new path, or if not, it will naturally be difficult for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Mr. Romeva, do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the main character?
I think that's fine, I wouldn't have any problem.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the legacy received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst legacy ever left by any government, when they received the best legacy ever had by any government.
Mr President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper that Spain and Argentina are in dispute over an oil company.
This is simply the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina and, beyond that, with that great European value which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in the original or derived Community law to neutralize the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr President, in the Committee on Agriculture we share the ultimate goal of this Directive, which is to try to use taxation to guide the composition of our energy mixes. However, this is a very complex debate.

full of challenges in the economic, social, and environmental spheres, it is important to maintain those balances that help us make more progress in the environmental sphere, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and do not create greater social crises than the ones we are already experiencing.
This is the case with agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural holdings, at a time when, moreover, we are in a debate that combines the crises of the raw materials markets with a perspective of aid and an increase in health and environmental requirements that are growing margins of profitability.
That is why we have fundamentally asked for two things.

The first is the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of the
agriculture within sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also be able to access the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions bracket.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains the balances that make our rural areas viable at a time of change and uncertainty.
we are experiencing a major controversy that is fundamentally based on the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you listen to the noise that is being created, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these days.
nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact that is precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since 1997.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those on regional cohesion and research, are growth-oriented policies that aim to promote the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I am addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the most chance of being heard, we will not have any complexes when it comes to engaging in that debate, which we can face with our heads held high.
This is, in my opinion, a minority view among those not registered.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their help with this report, which has made it much stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, a key factor in overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism.
and trust, transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Barnier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly of vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This obliges us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-cutting analysis that takes into account the different needs, capacities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
While an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive or of the options available or of their lack of knowledge of the existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

This is why, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been shown to be higher and where the greatest number of consumer complaints are registered, the financial sector, whose complexity means that, in potential, any consumer can become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is urged to redouble its efforts to provide comprehensible, truthful information, with clear explanations and direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising,

of foods high in fats, salt and sugar and to children and young people who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods the transport sector which still often struggles when vulnerable people travel the energy and telecommunications sector

where the lack of transparency causes, in some cases, an added difficulty for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may find it difficult to access the mechanisms
resistant.
That is why we are asking the Commission and the Member States, and allow me to sound a warning note to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr Gallardón, not to backtrack on rights.
and it goes against the trend of these difficult times to use intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.

Finally, I would like to conclude by stating that any one of us can become a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much and I would like to thank all the deputies for their help in strengthening this report.
Mr President, Commissioner, the truth is that I have a sense of hopelessness, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone.
it's going to allow me to do it this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had recently in this House on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are soaring in some Member States, we are already close to the

fifty percent of the working-age population, while many of them are already running out of any kind of social or unemployment coverage, while all of this is happening, while we are moving from a situation that is evolving from being worrying to being

from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission presents itself, once again, in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true government of the Union, which is what it is and, moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, governing means setting priorities, taking the lead, and, moreover, with the aim of achieving a goal, an objective, and, furthermore, the Commission is not doing this.

Governing is not about making a simple restructuring of funds, or even making and announcing it, in order to save face before public opinion, but about raising an ambitious, lasting and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not about resigning in the face of a youth unemployment rate above twenty percent and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

Governing is not about giving in to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other member states of the Council that are trying to convince us that the only way out of this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, is by giving up wages, labor rights, or compensation, that our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country and it is not.
This is true of Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of relationships and a model of labor rights and guarantees.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a right of citizenship; it is an instrument of connection with the system, an instrument of social integration.

Therefore, the more unemployment, the greater the political disaffection. That is why, Commissioner, I am not satisfied with you talking about issues of competence in order to do nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when you have had to interpret the Treaties in a lax manner to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so, and when the Treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of a Member State regarding austerity, we have also done so.
So, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have it, for example, the youth employment guarantee doesn't need to be explained to you.

Advocate for increased funding, use the European Social Fund as a tool if necessary, design a funded and supportive implementation mechanism that helps those with the highest unemployment rates the most, push to further change this policy of social suffocation on the countries that are faring the worst, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is struggling.
So, you will think, as I do, that the least important thing is who the competition belongs to, because for the citizens as a whole, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the INTA Committee for the work carried out, as well as the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs.

Overall, we are dealing with a good GSP regulation, which is necessary, particularly in some actions, to control the rules for importing textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of certain countries classified as upper-middle-income countries, such as those in Latin America, from the GSP.
Because, what about these middle-income countries that have undiversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a criterion for export diversification?

Because two speeds could be produced in this scenario, countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we must support a transition period and that amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation for these countries and give them the opportunity to open negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr President, I already supported Mrs Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo together with other parliamentarians, and I indeed saw that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest will to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, also needs to believe in its State and its Government, and that will not be possible only with electoral support or with external support.
They also need there to be a demand for the fight against corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the countries richest in resources in the world.

And it must be said and denounced that part of the violence they experience is imported or, at least, encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or other states, are capable of participating in corruption without caring that they encourage struggles over those resources in order to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

That is why, Mrs. Aston, although it is not strictly within your purview, I do say that greater demands for traceability and transparency from European multinationals and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at the electoral level and at the technical level.
Mr President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.

Colleagues, we are now debating package two, after having approved package six, after almost all the heads of state and government agreed on two international treaties outside of the established order.
communitarian, after many other European regulations have created more community authorities for banking supervision, stock market supervision, insurance supervision, and for economic system risks.
an array of texts and more texts of reports, proposals that address new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new protocols.
procedures. We must not stop and apply what we already have approved.
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, what is needed is just the opposite: stability and legal security.
We do not need a mishmash of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation that the rescue entails is very worrying.
Spanish citizens are not being told the whole truth about the new debt, which, by guaranteeing private debt, the Spanish government and state are assuming as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously said it did not want, and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues warned in this debate.
There is no triumph, only failure with Bankia and others.

I insist, there is no more correct policy for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must close, for we will not emerge from debt without harmonious growth of all and of the whole.

Supervision as called for in the two reports, yes, all the supervision that is necessary, but simultaneous growth is essential, anti-speculative as well, as alluded to in some of the measures of both reports and other reports too.
Please, clarity and transparency too, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo said before.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have continually denounced female genital mutilation.
that silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls around the world suffer - seventy million, I repeat, seventy million

an unbearable figure for anyone who takes the time to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which hide behind the guise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of which are false.

The truth is that ablation, performed preferably on girls as young as fourteen and even one year old, can lead to death by hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological consequences due to trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, so that the law in Europe speaks with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was to gradually adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas by 2015.

But it is also true that every time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases due to the lack of a clear exit strategy, and the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us regarding the decision we have to make also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and whether

we will have had time to make a serious assessment of them and also reasons such as the uncertainty about where the common agricultural policy is heading and especially its budget, that is, about the part of the income that does not come from the markets and that affects our producers.

So, what we are asking you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos, is that we do not engage in a makeshift policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

postpone the end of the quota until 2015, until a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on the regulation mechanisms, because the markets are still more unfair and the producers are increasingly defenseless.
Mr President, many Members of this Parliament have listened to the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have said that this is a yes or no agreement.
We Members of this Parliament also have a responsibility to vote 'yes' or 'no'.
And we say no because this agreement causes confusion, as is evident.
intellectual property rights and the rights of internet users are not clarified.
Internet users, do we care about intellectual property rights?
yes
yes, it is ACTA solution.
No, it is not a solution, because there are two issues to address - it is not a legal issue, but two political issues: a determination of the fight against counterfeiting and the
piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we in the Socialist Group have repeatedly requested, and we are requesting it again.
It's your chance.
Do not turn your back on society because tomorrow you will find that you cannot and you will have no way out.
improve, that time it is necessary to emphasize the chaos.
The sense of powerlessness was of such magnitude that Europe had to react, and it has done so for the good of all, because the big winner of this past Summit has been the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis by moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, ladies and gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to adopt long-term measures to address the shortcomings of the Union.
In this case, the immediate was essential in order to continue working towards what was important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, such important decisions as the one to empower the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish government.
In addition, it will serve to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their commitments regarding public deficit and reforms.
These were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which must be the European Union's top priority in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and put obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reformist agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Moreover, it is carrying out a financial reform based on total transparency, all of which demonstrates its commitment to fiscal consolidation and meeting deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr President, from the outset, the Community and then the European Union have always been not only capable of overcoming crises, but of emerging stronger from them.
I'm glad that once again we are going to succeed.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on the banks, which we repeatedly hear described as the lifeblood of the social body.
This image is probably accurate, but let's keep in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and the joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.
And, moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically intended for these purposes, and open, in addition, to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear support for these projects.

Mr President, dear Commissioner, Minister, as I greet the new Presidency, I am a veteran member of the now-defunct Non-Aligned Movement that your country led, and I fervently wish for the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and gentlemen, we should have taken the opportunity for a more comprehensive reform of the Court, perhaps, but the Commission's and my colleague's proposal are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity they received in our Committee.
The agility and smooth functioning of the Court are essential, which I question with the new jurisdiction's delayed patent proceedings today.
Congratulations to the opponent. Proceed with the reform of the Court.

Mr President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the Popular Party came to power, with repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who disagree, including consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, trampling among others on articles sixteen and seventeen of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a dangerous attack.

not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, which are basic principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore call for rectification by the government of Mr. Rajoy in the face of the outrage of outlawing FACUA, and I appeal to the Commission to ensure the protection of
defend the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of rights and the functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, I first of all want to highlight the excellent work of Mrs Macavan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs in reaching this point.
first reading agreement, which was very important, since it brought into force the regulation that we had approved in 2010 and it was necessary to revise it.
not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but, as has been said, recent events occurred that are well known and demonstrated that there was a certain
it was necessary to correct it so that it would not happen again and specific points of vigilance and security of the medicines once marketed had to be reinforced.

Therefore, from now on, as stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw or request withdrawal or suspend the authorization will have the possibility of being authorized.
obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or suspension of a medicinal product's authorization.
This is a major achievement in the name of transparency and will prevent the marketing authorization holder from attempting to hide the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions is carried out in a third country, all the concerned Member States where this medicinal product is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and safety without overburdening the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies.

The second important change that has been achieved is that all authorized products that are subject to a post-authorization safety study are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Lastly, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and that is why this plenary must approve this proposal.

Mr President, I want to thank once again all those who have made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I have forgotten and all the colleagues who have been with us.

I want to say to the victims, all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinction, that for us, they and their families have a face, they have a name, they are real, and it is precisely in their name.

we will work to ensure that this Directive is not just a dead letter, but that, with the commitment and help of Commissioner Reding, which I have absolutely no doubt about, it is implemented quickly and effectively, which is what we all hope for and what everyone wants.

And I am sure that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many others that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When people in my country ask me what I do in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of the victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me a lot of strength to continue working.

I am sure that, with the support and commitment, not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will all manage, together with the support of your lordships, to rescue the victims from that unjust oblivion.

The rapporteur's work, Mr President, is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can see.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught us, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must employ all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it generates a malicious network where traps lurk and arbitrariness takes hold.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the public in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers, to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the legislator's courtesy and a way of demonstrating their respect for the citizen.

ignorance. You know the Spanish Constitution.

Because what the vice president, Mr. Vidal Cuadras, has said is nothing more or less than applying what is stated in the Spanish Constitution. The rest are singular personal opinions that are completely irrelevant and that I can respect but that I despise.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and that is pacta sunt servanda, that is, agreements are meant to be kept.
By this I mean the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased and they have welcomed decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro in an irreversible manner.
The European Council held last week contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards banking union are satisfactory.
The agreement to twenty-seven for the launch of the banking supervisor is also positive. Finally, it is appropriate that the launch be entrusted to the Eurozone's Ministers of Economy.
but it will allow you to make a critical judgment of the biased interpretations that have been made of it unilaterally.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make private interpretations that may distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we approve of presenting as agreements matters that were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are indisputable: increased competition, a greater range of products and services.
services, creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, still not enough and we cannot become complacent.

A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and reinforce citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in last week's Communication.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis obliges us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr President, I too want to congratulate the rapporteur and the rest of the colleagues who have worked on this reform so well.

The financial crisis has been exacerbated by the existence of complex and strange negotiable securities that are linked to derivative instruments and negotiations outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns at great speed.
It is necessary to attract financial operations to a transparent market to ensure the proper formation of prices and competition among tradable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information provided is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge to give free consent to the risks they are taking on.
Transparency is of no use as a great flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.

Mr President, we are debating four reports today that represent a revitalisation of our common security and defence policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in the face of the minority Eurosceptic sectors that also dominate in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Dan Jan, whom I would like to thank for his spirit of consensus-seeking during its preparation, contains important contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European Defence Strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
it is that of cybersecurity and cyber defence, a report that we also debated today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European Cybersecurity Strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis in which the member states are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European projects are most necessary.
That is why it is more important than ever to reinforce the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being strongly contested today.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with President Van Rompuy's project for the December 2013 Council.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, the defence of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Given the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to reach a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our opinion, unacceptable.
A reduction of seventy-five million euros on the already inevitably meager proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And not only that, the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain indicated from the beginning of the negotiations.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to argue about a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices for deficit correction.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, you're not getting anywhere. On the contrary, the budget line is like a missile.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with much fewer resources, especially if what there is is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply means the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, who should be thanked for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cádiz interpreting the Treaties for a supposed secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken into account and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the benefit of all.
